div.p: A CONFERENCE Between a Sick man, and a Minister, shewing the nature of Presumption, Despaire, and the true living Faith.

q.p: In the Lord shall all the seed of Israel be justified, and glory.
I determined not to know any thing among you, save Jesus Christ, and him crucified.

div.p: By HEN. DENNE, an unworthy Minister of Christ Iesus, at Pyrton in Hertfordshire.

div.head: To my vvelbelov'd Friends, and Brethren in the Lord, the Inhabitants of Pyrton, in the County of Hertford, greeting in the Lord Iesus.
div.p:
DEarely Beloved in the Lord, I present these things to your view; that you may see in a briefe Conference the summe of that Doctrine, which (through the grace of God) I haue taught and you beleeved. I confesse you have cause to say, that you have heard many things
from me, which are not here mentioned: Yet this you will witnes on my behalf, that here is nothing set down which you have not before heard. I have in this present discourse imitated the Geographer, who intending to describe a large Countrey in a small Map, contenteth himselfe to set down the chiefe Towns, and let the smaller Villages, passe without any mention. Thus have I (being to draw the substance of 10 yeares Sermons into a few lines) contented my selfe, with the Description of the most materiall and fundmentall Doctrines, which I have delivered unto you. And this I have done, not only to testifie my unfained love, which I beare unto you, and my ardent desire that your soules
may prosper. But also to signifie unto the World, that I am ready to give an account of my Faith, and to defend my Doctrine (against all opposers) from such clamors and aspersions as have been always laid upon it, But especially when I delivered this Sermon, which you have seene already. And I am confident I shall be able to do this, through the grace of God, given unto me, by your ardent prayers to God for me, that utterance may be given me, that I may open my mouth boldly, and declare the mystery of the Gospell, to his glory, and your consolation. The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.

closer.signed: Your most unworthy Minister HEN. DENNE.

div.head: A CONFERENCE Between a Sick man, and his Pastor: wherein after ordinary salutations given, and received; the Sick man beginneth thus.

p.hi: SIr what judge you of my spirituall estate and condition?

sp.speaker: Minister.
sp.p: Charity judgeth the best; but what man knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit of a man which is in him.

p.hi:
I have a stedfast hope in
Almighty God, that I shall be saved when I dye.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Blessed is he that is able to give a reason of the hope that is in him, with meeknesse and feare.

p.hi: I have many reasons of my hope, first, I have an earnest desire to be saved above all thinks in the world.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: This reason may deceive you; For it is written, Many shall seek, to enter and shall not be able.

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.p: How then doth the promise stand good; Aske and it shall be given you, seek and ye shall find, knock and it shall be opened, Mat. 7.7, 8.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: This promise is not made unto every particular person, but only to the Disciples and in them to all beleevers, Matth. 21.22. Whatsoever ye shall aske in prayer, if ye beleeve ye shall receive it, and John 15.7. If ye abide in me and my words abide in you, aske what ye will and it shall be done to you. See also Mark, 11.24.

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.p:
What say you to this gracious promise?
Blessed are they which hunger and thirst after righteousnesse, for they shall be filled, Mat. 5.6.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I say to this as to the former: that this promise is made only to beleevers, Luke 6.20. And he lifted up his eyes upon his Disciples and said, Blessed are ye that hunger, &c. Is it not sayd, blessed are they that mourn? yet are not all mourners blessed.

p.hi: I have heard, and I thinke reade, that a desire to beleeve is Faith it selfe.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: The poore man can tell you that, to be rich, and to desire to be rich, are two things; even so is Faith and a desire to Beleeve, as all that desire to be rich, are not rich; so all that desire to beleeve, do not beleeve.

p.hi: Have I thus beene deceived?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
It is requisite that you first prove your self a beleever & mÄ“ber of Christ than may you apply these promises to
selfe, otherwise not so, He that beleeveth shall be saved; He that beleeveth not shall be damned, Mark. 16.16.

p.hi: Can you shew me any that have sought God, and not found him?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Yes very many, for thus we read; They shall call upon mee, but I will not answer: They shall seek me early, but they shall not find mee, Prov. 1.28. Mich. 3.4. Psal. 109. Let his prayer become sin.

p.hi: These all sought freedome from temporall punishments only?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You speake more than you have warrant, for I will shew you men seeking after righteousnesse, yet have not attained unto it.

p.hi: Then I shall heerein be satisfied?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: We read plainly, that Israel that followed after the Law of righteousnesse, hath not attained unto the Law of righteousnesse, Rom. 9.31. and 10.20.

p.hi: They sought it not in Faith.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
You say true, neither have you
proved, that you seeke it in Faith, which so soon as you shall do, I will be ready to minister words of comfort unto you.

p.hi: Who can hold that which will away? I have used carefully all meanes appointed to Salvation, for the attaining thereof.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: These all, may be cut short with; One thing lackest thou yet, Marke 10.21. Let mee heare you give instance.

p.hi: I have had a care to keepe God's Law, to do all things commanded, and to shun all things forbidden, to the uttermost of my power: and this is the second reason of my hope.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: This I hardly beleeve it is like that in the Gospell. All these things have I kept from my youth. But if it be true, what can this reason availe seeing, by the deeds of the Law, no flesh can be justified, as it is written, Rom. 3.20.

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.p: Is it not said? Blessed are they that keep his testimonies, Psal. 119.2.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Have you then kept the Law of God with your whole heart?

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.p: No, neither can any man keepe it; but I have had a desire to keepe it, and God accepts the will for the deed.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: How can that be generally true? seeing the Law saith, Cursed is every one that continueth not in all things that are written in the Book of this Law, to do them, Gal. 3.10. Whereby it is plaine, that the Law requires under paine of curse, not only to will, but also to do.

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.p: Is it not not written? If there be, first, a willing mind, it is accepted according to that a man hath, and not according to that he hath not, 2 Cor. 8.12.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
When the person is first accepted, the will is accepted for the deed: So God accepteth of Abraham, as though he had offered his son, Gen. 22.16. But the person not accepted, the will cannot be accepted for
the deed: before you can assure your selfe by this will; you must see that your person be accepted.

p.hi: Cannot a man attaine to life by keeping of the Law of God?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Yes, if he keepe it in all and every point without any breach at all, Rom. 2.7. Deut. 11.26, 27. but not otherwise, for he that offendeth in one is guilty of all, James 2.10.

sp.speaker: Sick
sp.p: Why then doth our Saviour direct the young-man in the Gospell this way, Math. 19 17.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You might have asked as well to what purpose serveth the Law? and I should have answered you, that it was added, bocause of Transgressions, Gal 3.19.

p.hi: How do you apply this to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
As the Law was given, that all might be concluded under sin, Gal. 3.22. Rom. 3.9. That all the world might become guilty before God: So doth our Saviour give this direction
unto this young man, not that he thought it possible for him to attaine life thereby: But that he might discover the pride, arrogancy, and deceitfulnesse of his heart, and answer him according to his own question.

p.hi: If I should instance in private prayer to be a marke of my Salvation. I so already it might after the same manner be rejected, unlesse I could prove it to proceed from Faith.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You say true, workes indeed are an evidence of Faith among men, in the judgement of Charity, James 2.18. But Faith is an evidence of our works in the Court of Conscience, and judgement of certeinty: for even the prayer of the wicked is abominable, and whatsoever is not of Faith is sin, Rom. 14.23.

p.hi: What thinke you of true repentance, is not that a sure marke of Salvation?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Without faile.

p.hi:
Then Here is comfort for
mee, for I have truly Repented.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Not he that approveth himselfe is accepted, but he whom the Lord approveth, 2 Cor. 10 18. How know you your repentance to be true?

p.hi: By two things, the first is, I have a hearty sorrow for all and every one of my sins.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: All that do truly repent, do indeed heartily sorrow for sin, 2 Cor. 7.10. But all that do heartily sorrow for sin do not truly repent.

p.hi: Did ever any reprobates sorrow heartily for their sins?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Yes, Cain, Genesis 4.13. Esau, Gen. 27.38. Judas, Matthew 27.3. Judas repented himselfe, and doubtlesse all that despaire do heartily sorrow for sinne, as they that are swallowed up with over much sorrow, 2 Cor. 2.7.

p.hi:
I do not only sorrow for mysins, but I have also a stedfast purpose to
forsake all sinne, and to walke in all godlinesse.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Doth not our Lord Iesus tell you, that except your righteousnesse do exceed the righteousnesse of the Scribes and Pharisees, ye cannot enter into the Kingdome of God? Math. 5.20.

p.hi: Had any of the Scribes and Pharisees a purpose to lead a godly life?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Heare what S. Paul (a Pharisee) saith of himselfe, that before his Conversion he was as touching the righteousnesse that is in the Law, blamelesse, Phil. 3.6. Acts 22.

p.hi: Yea but Paul persecuted the Church of God.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: This indeed was a great, but yet unknown sin, but in his conceit a vertue, Phil. 3.6. 1 Tim. 1.13. This also may be your error, to thinke you do God service, when you sin hainously.

p.hi: Is it ordinary for men to be zealous before true conversion to God?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
You see the unconverted Iews, of whom the holy Ghost giveth
testimony. First, that they have a zeale to God. Secondly, that they seeke to establish their own righteousnesse, Rom. 10.2.3.

p.hi: I know not what more to say: if this be not true repentance, I pray what is?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: That shall be shewed anon, let us first heare what other evidence you have of Salvation?

p.hi: I have but one only stay more, if that also faile, Lord have mercy on me.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Let me heare that stay also.

p.hi: I love Gods people unfainedly, with all my heart, what thinke you of this?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Take heed your heart deceive you not, and that this prove not also a reed to leane upon.

p.hi: How? This also a reed to leane on, Why then nothing will please you, I see, 'twill be but in vaine to talke any further.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Be patient (deare brother) and give me leave to search your wound to the quick, I hope it shall through Gods grace, turne to your soules welfare in Christ Iesus.

sp.speaker: Sick.
sp.p: Doth not Saint John say plaine, We know we have passed from death to lif, because we love the brethren? 1 Joh. 3.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I deny not but where unfained love to the brethren is sound it may be a testimony of grace received? But I demand how you know you love the brethren?

p.hi: Why how should I know?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: By this we know, If we love God and keep his Commandements, 1 Joh. 5.2. and this is his Commandement, that we should beleeve on the name of his Son Jesus Christ, 1 John 3.23. So that unlesse we beleeve truly, we cannot know we love unfainedly, therefore though our love beare witnesse to our Faith before man, yet our Faith beares witnesse to our love in the secrets of our heart; neither can it ever appeare to be true love, that proceedes not from a heart first imbracing Christ by Faith.

p.hi:
What you call true Faith, I know not: I feele my heart inflamed
with love to the Brethren.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Take heed your heart deceive you not; do not you know some of the children of God, and your brethren in great poverty?

p.hi: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Why then have you not sold either the whole, or halfe of your possessions and divided among them?

p.hi: Can I not love them unlesse I sell my possessions and divide among them?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Verily no, for true love bindeth us not only to lay down our goods, for the brethren, as Acts 2.45. but also our lives, where need requireth, 1 John 3.16, 17.

p.hi: I confesse I have not thus loved them.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Then have you loved them in word, and not in deed, in tongue and not in truth, 1 Joh. 3.18.

p.hi: I doe beleeve that there are very few that by this marke can be assured of Salvation.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I am of your mind, for when we consider our love to our brethren, to come so far short of the precept and example of our Lord, and his holy Apostles, we shall have greater cause to feare, than otherwise.

p.hi: What then should Saint John meane?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I do for the present beleeve untill I shall see ground to the contrary, that Saint John doth principally speake of our assurance, whereby we know one another to be the children of God: By this shall all men know ye are my Disciples, if ye love one another, John 13.35. Yet do I not deny but that love or any other vertue having first received testimony from Faith, may be thereby qualified to beare witnesse together with Faith, and no otherwise.

p.hi: But when I cannot see I beleeve, and yet do perceive that I love.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
The light of the soule is Faith: if Faith be obscured, shall
not love be much more darkened?

p.hi: Alas, this was my only stay!

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I dare affirme that he that hath no greater witnesse in himselfe than love to the brethren, shall never attaine unto assurance of Salvation, 1 John 5.10.

p.hi: Is there any greater witnesse than love?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Yes, which I wonder you have not seen as yet; the Spirit of God bearing witnesse to our spirits, that we are the children of God, Rom. 8.15, 16. Now the Spirit beareth witnesse by teaching us to cry, Abba father.

p.hi: Oh, that I had such a spirit, but woe is me, How have I hitherto been deceived? how have I also deceived others? my stayes are broken, and I shall bee cast head-long to hell.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Say not so.

p.hi:
Yes, cursed be the time that ever I laid a foundation upon the sands. I had thought Righteousnesse hod been mine, Heaven mine, but now Hell gapeth
for me, and I shall be damned.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: As you have been hitherto deceived, so I hope you are also now.

p.hi: Alas how is it possible that I should now learne the ways of salvation? When as I (as you see) have laboured so many yeares in vaine, and profited nothing at all in true godlinesse?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Be not discouraged, only be content to heare what the Lord will speake.

p.hi: Alas, I have scarce an houre to live, and is it possible to work out Heaven in an houre? Is it possible that one houres repentance should make amends for sixty yeares ignorance?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You multiply words without knowledge, which are no lesse than blasphemy: How do you thinke that amends can be made by you, when sixty yeares repentance cannot make amends for one houres negligence, and you understand not what you say when you talke of working out Heaven.

p.hi: Are there not many things to be done by us, before we can be saved?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: What judge you? when it is said, God hath saved us and called us not according to our works; but according to his own purpose, and grace which was given us in Christ Jesus before the world began, 2 Tim. 1.9. Is it not spoken mystically, as well as literally? Their strength is to sit still, Esay, 30.9. In returning and rest shall ye be saved, in quietnesse and confidence, shall be your strength, Esay 30.15. I might adde to this, stand still and behold the salvation of the Lord.

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.p: These indeed are comfortable words, But this quencheth all, in that it is said, narrow is the way, strait is the gate, and few there be that find it.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: This contradicteth not what hath been said, Narrow it is indeed, and strait to flesh and bloud, which cannot inherit the Kingdome of God, 1 Cor. 15. So narrow that the greatest wisdome of man cannot find it, 1 Cor. 2.8.

p.hi: Alas! how shall I do then?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Yet not so strait, but even fooles may find it when God teacheth, 1 Cor. 1.7. and how comfortable are the words of our blessed Saviour: Father, I thanke thee that thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and revealed them to babes. Are not all things possible to God?

p.hi: Did any ever learne the way to Heaven in so short a time, as I have to live.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Yes, the Thiefe upon the Crosse, Math. 27.44. Luke 23.42. The Iews at Peters Sermon, Acts 2.41. The Iaylor, Acts 16.33. with divers others.

p.hi: Now my heart reviveth within me: The Lord teach me also: and I humbly beseech you to do your best endeavour.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: God forbid that I should hide any thing from you, do you acknowledge your selfe a wretched sinner?

p.hi: Oh miserable man that I am! Who shall deliver me from this vile estate?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Do you thinke any creature is able to deliver you or can you, deliver your selfe?

p.hi: Help Lord, for vaine is the help of man; who shall be able to take away my sins?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Heare the goodnesse of our God, who hath sent his only begotten Son Jesus Christ, to take our nature upon him, Heb. 2.16.

p.hi: This I beleeve.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: This blessed Son of God, was conceived by the holy Ghost, borne of a Virgin, was without spot of fin, and in our nature hath wrought all righteousnesse, and therefore by vertue of this his righteousnesse, might have challenged all blessings promised to the obedient, Luk. 1.32. Mat. 3.1 Pet. 2.22. Deut. 28.

p.hi: This I also beleeve to be most true.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
This same Iesus who might have challenged a blessing and freedome from the curse, yet was he contented
to become a curse for us, and to suffer reproach and shame, and the death of the Crosse: Gal. 3.13.

p.hi: I beleeve that Christ suffered such things indeed.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: This same Iesus hath God raised up; having loosed the paines of death, for it was not possible he should be holden of it. Act. 2.24.

p.hi: This also I beleeve.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: By vertue of this precious death and satisfactory sacrifice of Iesus Christ, Wee are reconciled to God, and have received attonement, Romans 5.10, freedome from all sinne, with perfect righteousnesse. Rom. 4.25.6.10.

p.hi: I pray have patience, this is more then I yet beleeve, that Christ hath fully freed any from all sinne in this life.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
Yes, from the imputation of sinne, as is plaine, by him yee are justified from all things, Act. 13.39. and the bloud of Jesus Christ his Son purgeth us
from all sin, 1 John 1.9. See Ephe. 5.27 and Col. 1.22. To make you holy and unblameable and without fault, &c.

p.hi: This I cannot deny, yet do I not so fully conceive it.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Christ Iesus our Lord hath taken our sins upon himselfe, Esay 53.4 2 Cor. 5.21. and by his death and suffering hath given a full perfect and sufficient satisfaction to God the Father, Matthew, 3.17. Heb. 10.14. as having borne all punishments due unto sin by the Law, as wel temporal as eternall.

p.hi: That Christ Jesus hath freed his elect from all eternall punishments, I confesse, but I do not beleeve that hee hath freed them from temporall.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I will aske you one question; was not the satisfaction of the second Adam, as effectuall to our righteousnesse, as the transgression of the first Adam to our unrighteousnesse?

sp.speaker: Sick
sp.p: I dare not say the contrary, for the Apostle saith no lesse, Rom. 5.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: But by the transgression of the first Adam, we were made subject both to temporall and eternall punishments; Therefore by the satisfaction of our Lord Christ, the second Adam, we are made free from both.

p.hi: Yet do we not see that the people of God have many punishments laid upon them, in this present life, as weaknes, sicknesse, death?

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p: They are fatherly chastisements rather than punishments, for when we are judged we are chastened of the Lord, that we should not be condemn'd with the world, 1 Cor. 11.32.

p.hi: Let God be just, and every man a lyar, I pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: By vertue of the Lord Christs satisfaction unto Divine Iustice, Gods wrath is appeased, Mat. 3.17 Sin is taken away, John 1, 29. Never to be remembred any more, Heb. 8.12.

p.hi:
Lord, so take mine away. But I
pray when is the time that sin is taken away out of the sight of God.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Remission of sin is even as ancient as satisfaction for sinne, and at what time Christ Iesus taketh our sinnes upon himselfe, at the same time are the persons of Gods elect just before the Tribunall of Almighty God.

p.hi: I pray shew us authority for this, for I have alwayes learned that faith it selfe, is in order of causes before our actuall justification in the sight of God.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
That the act of our faith is a consequent of our Iustification, and not an intercedent, is plaine: God justifieth the ungodly: We were reconciled to God, by the death of his Sonne when we were enemies: Rom. 5.10. Now beleevers cannot be called enemies, but friends. But we were reconciled when we were enemies. Esay 32.17. the effect of righteousnesse is assurance. They that are ingrafted into Christ Iesus are justified:
But we must be ingrafted into Christ Iesus before we can beleeve, Therefore we must be justified before we can beleeve.

p.hi: How do you prove we must be ingrafted into Christ Jesus before we can beleeve?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: To beleeve is a good fruit, but we can beare no good fruit untill we be ingrafted into Christ Iesus: I am the Vine, yee are the branches; without mee yee can doe nothing: Iohn 15.5. The branch cannot beare any fruit except it bee incorporated into the Vine.

sp.speaker: Sic.
sp.p: Do we not read, whom he hath called, them he justified? where you see that justified is set before called.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.p:
The order of words prove nothing: was it not a ridiculous conceit of the Rabbi, that undertakes to prove unto us, that a certain bullock had horns before hoofs, because it is said Ps. 69. better then a bullock which hath horns and hoofes, and have you forgotten that place which I
spake of even now, who hath saved us and called us? where you see saved set before called.

p.hi: I now see plainly that the world is in darknesse, I do perceive that justification in Gods sight, goeth before faith: but I do not yet perceive that remission should be as ancient as satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: S. Peter saith, that Christ bare our sins in his own body, on the tree, that we being delivered from sin, should live in righteousnesse, 1 Pet. 2.24, Saint John tels us Christ tooke them away: Behold yee the Lambe of God that taketh away the sinnes of the World: if the justice of God hath layd all our iniquities upon his backe, hath not his mercy taken them from us? If the Lord Christ did take them away, then are they no more.

p.hi: This is plaine.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: I can shew you this by many more arguments, when opportunity shall serve.

p.hi: I pray go forward where we left.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: This same Iesus is ascended up into heaven, and there he sitteth for ever, at the right hand of God, to make intercession for us; by vertue whereof, we have boldnesse of accesse unto the Throne of grace, knowing that as our persons are accepted, so are our prayers respected in his presence, Heb. 4.16. Iohn 16.23.

p.hi: These indeed are comfortable words to them that have Christ; but how shall Christ be made mine? what works are required of me before Christ can be made mine?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You erre greatly, neither knowing the scripture, neither the power of God, nor yet remembring what you granted even now.

p.hi: I pray shew me my errour.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: First Christ is not made ours, neither applied unto us, by any works of the Law. Gal. 3.2.11.

p.hi: This indeed is an errour.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
Your supposition is also absurd, namely, that it is possible for you to do good workes before you have Christ,
when as before we said, you must have Christ before you can do any good, works: without me ye can do nothing.

p.hi: This was my conceit indeed, that by working righteousnesse, a man was made righteous.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You see the contrary hath been proved true: First, make the tree good, and then his fruit good, Mat. 7. a man must first be righteous, before he can worke righteousnesse; good manners do not make a good man: but a good man worketh good manners.

p.hi: I acknowledge my blindnesse, I pray then how is Christ made ours?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Christ is made ours by Gods imputation or accounting. Rom. 4.3.9.

p.hi: I greatly desire to heare this more fully explained.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
Looke by what way or meanes our sins were made Christs, after the same manner, and by the same meanes, his righteousnesse is made ours: But our sins became his, by Gods accounting, as the Lord laid on him the iniquity of us all,
so by the same account of God (who calleth things that are not as though they were) his righteousnesse is made ours: as he became sinne for us, so are wee made the righteousnesse of God in him. Thus are we justified freely by his grace, by his bloud: Thus it is God that justifieth.

p.hi: I pray resolve me one doubt: How wee are said to bee justified by Faith.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Faith is taken two wayes; first, for the object of our faith: that is, the thing which wee do beleeve, as also hope is taken (Christ our hope) so we are justified by faith, that is, by the bloud of Iesus Christ. Secondly, faith is taken for the act of our faith, beholding the glorious object, and so wee are assured of our justification. Iustified before God by the object of our faith, assured by the act of our Faith, apprehending this object.

p.hi:
I perceive now that they only
are righteous whom God accounteth righteous, whose Salvation is wrought in Christ Iesus. How shall I know whether Christ hath satisfied for mee, and so whether God accounteth me righteous or not?

sp.speaker: Minist.
sp.p: The knowledge of this commeth by Faith, for the promise is made to beleevers, John 3.16. And this is the proper office of Faith, to bee perswaded of Gods mercy to us in particular, Romanes 8.38.

p.hi: Is nothing else required at our hands to procure assurance, but only to beleeve?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: When the soule is loaden with the burden of sin, and sence of misery, it is sufficient for assurance to beleeve God in his promises, and we read of nothing else, Acts 16.31. Beleeve in the Lord Iesus.

p.hi: What thinke you of Repentance? is not that also necessary?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
You now give me just occasion
to shew you that which before you desired; namely, what is true repentance.

p.hi: That have I longed for all this while; I pray declare it unto me.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Repentance is a contrition or sorrow for sin, which is joyned with Faith in the Lord Iesus Christ.

p.hi: You make Faith a part of Repentance, have you any authors for this?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Yes, as the learned know; But I wish you not to build your confidence on men, but upon the testimony of Gods Word.

p.hi: I pray shew me where this description can be warranted by Gods Word?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
That repentance under the new Covenant doth comprehend Faith wil be plaine, if you compare the 16. chap. of the Act. ver. 31. with Act. 2.38. in the first place the question is, what shall I do to be saved? the answer is, Beleeve, &c. In the 2. of the Act. the question is the same, and is answered by Peter, Repent and be baptized; therefore either
repentance must include Faith, or else S. Peter giveth not a full answer.

p.hi: This is very likely to be so, and there we see that they are bidden to repent, who were pricked in the heart already.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: It is said that John Bap. preached, Repent. &c. Mat. 3. S. Paul expounding this Act. 19.4. saith that Iohn preached the Baptisme of Repentance, saying that they should beleeve; what more plain than this?

p.hi: Why doth the holy Ghost use this word Repent?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: It is a very fit word, which signifieth, change your minds; now we know the people of the Iews, being under the Law, did seek to establish their own righteousnesse thereby, which being impossible, the holy Ghost doth very significantly use this word; that all men should repent (that is) change their minds and looke no longer for righteousnesse from the Law; but look unto the author of their salvation before promised, but now at the last manifested.

p.hi: Is not newnesse of life a part of Repentance?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Yes, Faith is our new life; the Just shall live by Faith, Rom. 1.17.

p.hi: Are not good works a part of Repentance?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: They are rather termed in the book of God fruits meet for repentance, Mat. 3.8. Act. 26.19. and fruits worthy of repentance, Luk. 3.8.

p.hi: Why are they so called?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Because they that repent, should be carefull above all things, to deny all ungodlinesse and worldly lusts, and to live soberly, righteously, and godly in this present world, Tit. 2.12.

p.hi: I remember I have read of Repentance & Faith, as two things in Scripture.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
I do not say they are altogether one and the same, but differ as the part and whole; moreover repentance is sometimes taken in Scripture for an alteration of some one particular act: But that which I have declared is what John and our blessed Saviour do mean by this word, Repent, for the Kingdome
of God is at hand.

p.hi: You said before, that for assurance I must beleeve, what must I beleeve?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: That God hath forgiven you your sins, and given you eternall life in his Son, 1 John 5.11.

p.hi: Can you shew me any reason why I should beleeve this, rather than Judas?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You must not looke at reason; but imitate father Abraham, who against hope beleeved in hope, Rom. 4.

p.hi: God doth not say to me in particular, that my sins are forgiven.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: If you will beleeve it, he speaketh to you in particular, for he speaketh to every beleever.

p.hi: I am a miserable sinner.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Otherwise what need had you of Christ, who came to call sinners? Consider not the greatnes of your sins, but be strong in Faith, giving glory to God, being fully perswaded that what he hath promised he is able to performe, Rom. 4.21. Though your sins were as red as scarlet, I will make them as white as snow, Esay 1.

p.hi: If I were as holy as Peter, or Paul, I could then beleeve.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Holinesse cannot go before Faith, but must follow it: look not upon your selfe, but upon the sufficient satisfaction of Christ Iesus, Come unto him loaden, and he shall ease you, Mat. 11.28. Thirsty, and he shall refresh you Ioh. 7. Empty, and he shall fill you, Lu. 1

p.hi: I am loaden, Lord ease me: How do men come by Faith?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Faith is the gift of God wrought in the heart by hearing of the Word of promise, Rom. 10.17. Gal. 3.2. which word hath been already spoken to you.

p.hi: Oh! How slow am I to beleeve? Lord help my unbeleefe; let me intreat you and the rest of this Christian company to call upon God, that I may beleeve and grow in this perswasion of the free pardon, and forgivenesse of sins in Christ Jesus.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p:
With all my heart, the Lord heare our prayer; O Lord thou art God which hast made Heaven and earth, and all that in them is; who by the
mouth of thy holy child Iesus, hast promised that whatsoever we aske in his name, thou wilt grant unto us. O Lord behold thy servant, and grant him thy grace, that he may be filled with thy holy Spirit; the spirit of Wisdom, and understanding, and revelation in the knowledge of Christ Iesus; that the eyes of his understanding being inlightened, he may know the hope of thy calling, and the riches of thine inheritance in the Saints, that he may be filled with righteousnesse and peace, and joy in the holy Ghost: Good Lord, sanctifie him wholly, and let his whole spirit, and soule, and body be preserved blamelesse, unto the comming of our Lord Iesus Christ, Amen.

p.hi: Amen, Amen. May it not prove presumption in me to beleeve the pardon of my sins?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Not so long as you beleeve them pardoned, not for your merit, but for Gods mercy sake.

p.hi:
My merit is nothing, his mercy is
over all; How great is the goodnesse of God toward me, who hath forgiven mine iniquity, and pardoned my sin! Lord now lettest thou thy servant depart in peace, for mine eyes have seen thy salvation.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Blessed be the Father of our Lord Iesus Christ, who leaveth us not destitute of his mercy.

p.hi: Now what shall I render unto the Lord for his mercy? for the forgivenesse of my sins, and the gift of his holy Spirit?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: You are to present your body a living sacrifice, holy, and acceptable unto God: and be not conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind, Rom. 12.

p.hi: The Lord direct me in all my ways, I desire to receive from your hands the holy Communion for the increase of my weake Faith, and in remembrance of the precious Passion of my Blessed Saviour: And now whether I live or dye, the halfe of my goods will I give to the poore, and if I have taken any thing from any man by forged accusation, I restore him fourefold.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Glory be to God, who can deny Salvation to be come to this house, forasmuch as it hath pleased God to begin this good worke? which he continue unto the end, through Iesus Christ our Lord, Amen.
